questions.question: What does the idiom 'eager beaver' mean?
options: A person who is always tired
A very enthusiastic and hard-working person
questions.explanation: 'Eager beaver' describes someone who is very enthusiastic and hard-working, always eager to do tasks.

questions.question: What does 'let the cat out of the bag' mean?
questions.explanation: This idiom means to reveal a secret accidentally or carelessly.

questions.question: What does 'a red rag to a bull' mean?
options: Something that makes someone very angry
questions.explanation: Something that is 'a red rag to a bull' is something that makes a person very angry or provokes them.

questions.question: What does 'cut a long story short' mean?
options: To be precise and get to the point
questions.explanation: 'Cut a long story short' means to tell only the essential parts and be precise.

questions.question: What does 'be all ears' mean?
questions.explanation: To 'be all ears' means to listen very attentively and with great interest.

questions.question: What does 'barking up the wrong tree' mean?
options: A dog barking at a tree
Doing something that will not get the result you want
questions.explanation: This idiom means pursuing the wrong course of action or looking in the wrong direction for a solution.

questions.question: What does 'break every rule in the book' mean?
questions.explanation: This idiom means to do something completely unacceptable or against all the rules.

questions.question: What does 'get on your high horse' mean?
questions.explanation: To 'get on your high horse' means to behave in a superior or arrogant manner.

questions.question: What does 'keep your nose to the grindstone' mean?
questions.explanation: This idiom means to continue working hard without taking a break.

questions.question: What does 'set the world on fire' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Set the world on fire' means to do something remarkable or extraordinary that gains a lot of attention.

questions.question: Which proverb means 'It is easier to stop something from happening than to repair the damage after it has happened'?
options: A stitch in time saves nine
The early bird catches the worm
Birds of a feather flock together
questions.explanation: 'Prevention is better than cure' means it's easier to prevent a problem than to fix it after it occurs.

questions.question: Which proverb means 'A true friend is one who helps you in times of trouble'?
options: Birds of a feather flock together
A friend in need is a friend indeed
The early bird catches the worm
questions.explanation: 'A friend in need is a friend indeed' means a real friend is one who helps you when you are in difficulty.

questions.question: Which proverb means 'Make the most of your opportunities'?
options: A stitch in time saves nine
Make hay while the sun shines
Half a loaf is better than no bread
questions.explanation: 'Make hay while the sun shines' means to take advantage of favorable circumstances while they last.

questions.question: What does 'A little knowledge is a dangerous thing' mean?
options: Having incomplete knowledge can lead to mistakes
questions.explanation: This proverb warns that having only partial knowledge about something can be more harmful than having no knowledge at all.

questions.question: What does 'Coming events cast their shadows before' mean?
options: Shadows are caused by the sun
There are often warning signs before something happens
questions.explanation: This proverb means that there are usually signs or hints that indicate what is going to happen in the future.

questions.question: What does 'Half a loaf is better than no bread' mean?
questions.explanation: This proverb means that having something, even if less than desired, is better than having nothing at all.

questions.question: What does 'Charity begins at home' mean?
options: You should first help your family and close ones before helping others
questions.explanation: This proverb means that one should first take care of their own family and close ones before extending help to others.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: He must abstain ___ all the things that are not good for him.
questions.explanation: 'Abstain from' means to keep away from something. The correct usage is 'abstain from'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: Father acceded ___ our suggestion immediately.
questions.explanation: 'Accede to' means to agree or consent to something. The correct usage is 'accede to'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: She was always accompanied ___ her mother.
questions.explanation: 'Accompanied by' means to go with someone. The correct usage is 'accompanied by'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: I completely agree ___ what the article suggests.
questions.explanation: 'Agree with' means to have the same opinion about something. The correct usage is 'agree with'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: He is addicted ___ playing video games.
questions.explanation: 'Addicted to' means obsessed with a particular activity. The correct usage is 'addicted to'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: Beware ___ chain snatchers in this area.
questions.explanation: 'Beware of' means to be cautious of something. The correct usage is 'beware of'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: She is capable ___ memorising a poem very quickly.
questions.explanation: 'Capable of' means able to do something. The correct usage is 'capable of'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: Very often children are compared ___ wet clay.
questions.explanation: 'Compare to' is used when comparing things that are different to note similarities. The correct usage here is 'compared to'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: The dessert consists ___ fruits, cream and sugar.
questions.explanation: 'Consist of' means to be made up of something. The correct usage is 'consist of'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: Sheena and her cousin differ ___ each other in several aspects.
questions.explanation: 'Differ from' means to be different from something. The correct usage is 'differ from'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: My uncle is engaged ___ reading the plays of Shakespeare.
questions.explanation: 'Engaged in' means to be occupied or involved in something. The correct usage is 'engaged in'.

questions.question: Which idiom means 'to listen very attentively'?
questions.explanation: 'Be all ears' means to listen very attentively and with great interest.

questions.question: Which idiom means 'to face the consequences of one's actions'?
options: Take the bull by the horns
questions.explanation: 'Face the music' means to accept the unpleasant consequences of your actions.

questions.question: If someone is 'on the mend', they are:
questions.explanation: To be 'on the mend' means to be recovering from an illness or injury.

questions.question: The proverb 'Still waters run deep' means:
options: A quiet person may have hidden depths
questions.explanation: This proverb means that a quiet or reserved person may have a lot more intelligence, knowledge, or emotions than they show.

questions.question: Which proverb advises to act quickly to prevent small problems from becoming big ones?
options: Birds of a feather flock together
A stitch in time saves nine
The early bird catches the worm
Make hay while the sun shines
questions.explanation: 'A stitch in time saves nine' means fixing a small problem immediately prevents it from becoming a bigger problem.

questions.question: What does 'A new broom sweeps clean' suggest about new people in charge?
options: They make many changes at first but may not continue
questions.explanation: This proverb suggests that new people in positions of authority often make many changes initially, but their enthusiasm may fade over time.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: Once Ajit makes a promise, he always abides ___ it.
questions.explanation: 'Abide by' means to follow or comply with something. The correct usage is 'abide by'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: They seem bent ___ going ahead with their programme.
questions.explanation: 'Bent on' means very determined to do something. The correct usage is 'bent on'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: He is blind ___ his sister's faults.
questions.explanation: 'Blind to' means to fail to notice something. The correct usage is 'blind to'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: She is content ___ whatever she has.
questions.explanation: 'Content with' means satisfied with something. The correct usage is 'content with'.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: I differ ___ you on the choice of material.
questions.explanation: 'Differ with' means to disagree with someone. The correct usage is 'differ with' when expressing disagreement.

questions.question: Choose the correct preposition: The two brothers constantly differ ___ some issue or the other.
questions.explanation: 'Differ on/over' means to disagree about some point or issue. The correct usage is 'differ on' or 'differ over'.
